abstract.p: Susan Stellin Practical Traveler column, in light of SARS outbreaks, on issue of airplane air quality; independent sources say there is not enough data to gauge effects of airplane air on travelers' health and more research is needed; drawing (M)

DESPITE assurances from health officials that there have been few instances of SARS transmission on aircraft, even the remote possibility of catching the respiratory disease while flying has rekindled concerns about a somewhat dormant issue: the effects of airplane air on travelers' health.

Although air quality inside the cabin has long been a concern, particularly to flight attendants, the issue has taken a back seat to safety, security and financial solvency in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.

While those continue to be priorities for the government and airlines, fears about SARS and the fact that it has been spread by travelers -- at least, after they land -- has drawn renewed attention to the question, should we be worried about the air we breathe for hours inside a jet?

The short answer, according to most independent sources, is that there isn't really enough data to say, which has led to the not particularly reassuring recommendation that more investigation is necessary.

The long answer can be found in a report released at the end of 2001 by the National Research Council, a government advisory group: The Airliner Cabin Environment and the Health of Passengers and Crew. Congress, concerned that other questions about cabin air quality had not been addressed, requested the report as a follow-up to a 1986 council study that resulted in the ban on smoking during domestic flights.

In the latest study, which was financed by the Federal Aviation Administration, a committee of experts was asked to assess the presence of various airborne contaminants on airplanes, evaluate their toxicity and effects on travelers' health and recommend ways to improve cabin air quality. Though the committee did not conduct original research, it reviewed dozens of earlier studies of aircraft air, finding most of them lacking in scientific rigor.
Limited Information

''We came to some conclusions, but we were limited in the judgments we could make by a severe lack of relevant data,'' said Morton Lippmann, the committee's chairman and a professor of environmental medicine at the New York University School of Medicine. In fact, a primary recommendation the committee made was that the F.A.A. provide quantitative evidence that its current regulations are adequate on issues like the amount of ventilation, the maximum cabin pressure allowed and acceptable levels of carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and ozone in the cabin.

More specifically, it recommended that high priority be given to researching such issues as the health effects of elevated ozone levels that can occur at high altitudes; whether current cabin pressure standards create health risks for infants, pregnant women, people with cardiovascular disease and other ''susceptible'' travelers; whether using recirculated cabin air increases the risk of exposure to infectious agents; and whether ''air-quality incidents'' like a hydraulic fluid leak can create health problems.

''Basically, the N.R.C report looked at the existing research and said more research needed to be done and we agreed with that,'' said Alison Duquette, an F.A.A. spokeswoman. Toward that end, the agency is preparing to put monitoring equipment on two aircraft and hopes to have some testing completed by next spring, but Ms. Duquette said it may be 2006 before testing is completed and it can be determined whether new rules are necessary. Meanwhile, public attention is primarily focused on the risk of catching an infectious disease while flying (which has not been the highest priority of air quality advocates, who have been more concerned with ventilation and contaminants). Dr. Lippmann said that while research suggested there was a ''minimal elevated chance'' of catching an illness from someone seated next to you and in adjacent rows, ''There's virtually no evidence to suggest there's a risk of everyone else on the plane getting sick.''
A Measure of Reassurance

With respect to SARS, Dr. Lippmann said heightened monitoring of suspected cases would have turned up evidence if there had been a cluster of SARS infections among passengers. ''What air transport does is bring an infectious person to Toronto from China,'' he said, ''But that's a different issue than spreading it among fellow passengers.''

That may reassure travelers nervous about flying with SARS dominating the news, but there is still a perception among frequent fliers that the cold they caught after a trip probably originated with a passenger coughing across the aisle. The N.R.C. committee report does not rule out that possibility. ''Transmission of infectious agents from person to person has been documented to occur in aircraft,'' the report states, citing influenza, measles and tuberculosis as diseases with documented cases of transmission on planes.

But the report also says the most important factors in these cases appear to be ''high occupant density and the proximity of passengers,'' not the aircraft ventilation system -- a conclusion that may seem like splitting hairs, but does raise the question of whether the airlines and manufacturers can realistically be expected to prevent all germs from circulating within the cabin.

''The problem is person-to-person contact -- and how do you prevent that?'' said Russell B. Rayman, another committee member, and executive director of the Aerospace Medical Association, which focuses on aviation and health. ''Of course, the answer is that people who have significant illnesses or contagious illnesses simply should not fly. But being realists, we know that people fly when they're ill. And that's true in your office, too -- when somebody comes in with the flu or a bad upper respiratory infection, you're at risk.''

In fact, airplane ventilation systems are designed to minimize the flow of air through the length of the cabin: in most newer planes, a mixture of fresh air (from outside the aircraft) and recirculated air (cabin air that has passed through a filter) is pumped in above each row and exhausted through vents near the floor in that same row. ''Air flow that comes into a seat row leaves from that seat row,'' said Dave Space, a Boeing scientist, explaining how this design minimizes the propagation of contaminants.

Aircraft manufacturers and the airlines insist that mixing recirculated air with fresh air -- a measure taken in recent years to save on fuel costs -- does not pose a health problem. But that is one of several issues the Association of Flight Attendants, a union representing members at 26 airlines, views as a matter of some debate. The union has advocated more research and new rules regarding ventilation, carbon monoxide monitoring and exposure to toxic or infectious agents in the air and feels the F.A.A. has dropped the ball on its regulatory responsibilities.

''There just hasn't been much government oversight over these kinds of things,'' said Christopher Witkowski, the union's director of air, safety and health. ''Right now, SARS has been a huge issue for everyone, but in the future there are going to be other agents and viruses that are going to challenge us.''
PRACTICAL TRAVELER SUSAN STELLIN contributes regularly to the Travel section.
